text: Previously, on "The Resident"...
My entire life, I've wanted
to be a surgeon, despite knowing
- I have one big obstacle to overcome. - You're dyslexic.
Tina's baby will go to a traditional family.
I'm so sorry.
I don't know what's going on with you,
but I'm gonna go to Waylon's.
Big world outside of the OR.
If you want to see it, that's where I'll be.
I'd like that.
Your mother has lung cancer.
You cannot come to Nigeria
with me.
- You are my sister. - And you are mine.
I wish things didn't have to be this way.
I wish I didn't have to leave Chastain.
The National Weather Service has issued a tornado watch
for Fulton County...
I think Fritz got a little wet,
but otherwise we are all okay.
Good. Here.
Thank you.
Hi, buddy.
- Hey, buddy. - Hey, little wet? That's okay.
Look at you getting all wet.
Hey... how about you don't go into work today?
Fritz needs you.
Well, the tornado's not supposed to touch down
anywhere near us.
Anyway, we're just as safe at Chastain as we are here.
Yeah, I was just thinking,
with all of your extra shifts, it's been a while since
I've seen you stand still.
Got to keep busy, otherwise all I think about
are all of the ways in which we could have kept Mina here.
We did everything we could.
Doesn't feel like it.
What's that?
It's from Mina.
She told me to give it to you if you started...
- Spinning out? - No. Yeah.
Very funny.
"Dear Nic...
"Please stop doing that thing you do when you feel guilty
"where you can't sit still.
Hmm.
"I know you need permission to let things go, so here,
"unclench your fist, let it go.
Last thing I want is to be an anchor around your neck. Mina."
She knows you almost as well as I do.
We better get going.
Bye, guys.

The tornado has changed course
and is now just outside metro Atlanta.
We're expecting a mass increase of catastrophic injuries.
Pull out the disaster carts.
Prepare the portable monitors.
- Clear the hallways. - Let's move, people!
We have incoming.
Hey, Piper, Wes, let's take her to Bay Four.
Seven-year-old girl, severe abdominal pain,
nausea, vomiting.
Slightly hypertensive. 400cc's normal saline given en route.
We wouldn't have brought her in because of the tornado,
but she collapsed; We didn't know what to do.
Uh, Dr. Bell is our doctor.
- We left him a message. - I can let him know you're here.
- Thank you. - On my count.
One, two, three.
Hey, I'm Dr. Feldman.
I'm gonna listen to your heart and lungs, okay?
- Hi. - Hey. - Hey.
What's going on, Sammie?
Ni hao, Dr. Bell.
It's her stomach pain. It's never been this bad.
And she's been having constant nosebleeds
these past few days.
Is it the tumors? Do you think they're getting worse?
Maybe, but we'll admit her
and look into why this is happening.
Sammie has a history of abdominal cancer.
The Ackermanns recently adopted her from China.
So let's finish the exam and I'll get a hold of Dr. Wong
for an urgent ENT consult.
Problems with parking?
So far so good.
Please have a seat, Dr. Cain.
Dr. Sutton is your new resident.
No, she isn't. I work alone.
It's my call. You've had residents before.
Yes, and they almost killed me on the table.
Now you want me to mentor someone
who's gunning for my job. No, thank you.
There's a lot I can learn from you.
I'm not looking to take your job.
Either you're lying or you lack ambition.
Either way, pass.
I haven't had a good run with attendings either.
They seem hellbent on ending my career.
Is this you selling yourself?
This is me being truthful. It's how I roll.
Make it work.
Both of you.
Oh, God.
It's a tornado.
It's coming right at us.
Code Yellow. Please seek immediate shelter.
Sir, we need to go.
What's going on?
Leela, we have to go. We're in the path of a tornado.
I know, I know.
I'm just trying to get him to come down.
Just gotta finish one thing.
Get down!
Everyone move quickly and safely, everyone take cover!
Come on, come on, hurry!
Everyone take cover, take cover!
- Safely and quickly, please. - Come on. Com e on.
- Let's go, let's go, let's go! - Are you sure everyone's okay?
- Here, take these. - Here.
- Here we go. - Take these.
- Get away from the glass. - Get away from the glass!
- Come on, hurry! - Check everyone's okay
- in that direction. Thank you. - Get in the corner.
This way. Go this way.
Thank you.
Get away from the glass!
Get away from the glass!
Hey, hey, hey! Guys, hey!
- Got to get away from there. - Get away from the glass!
Get away from the glass!

- You all right? - Yeah.

We should take a look at those.

Let's get this boy to the OR.
I'll call and let them know you're coming.
- Stay really still, okay? - Thank you.
- These guys are gonna take care of you. - Yeah.

How's the rest of the hospital?
Still assessing, but it seems like most of the medicine
and surgery floors were left unharmed.
Let's triage the red critical patients to the PACU.
Yellows to the atrium, greens to the cafeteria.
We're gonna need more hands.
Hey. You okay?
I think so. Are you?
Yeah. We got lucky.
Where's the guy that was working on the lights?
He was right behind us.
- Wait. - Oh, my God.
- Headache... - Okay.

Okay, Ted, listen to me
and just take it easy, okay?
You have a metal rod lodged in your skull,
so I need to gently elevate your head.
We need to elevate his head.
Okay, right here. Here.
All right. Ready?
One, two...
- Okay. - There we go.
All right, Ted, look at me. Good, good, good.
Deep breath.
Damn. He needs surgery.
We need to get him out of here.
We're gonna get you out of here.
Damn it.
We're trapped.
No one even knows we're here.
Conrad, Nic.
The ambulance bay roof collapsed.
I was out for a beat, but Piper's hurt real bad.
Her leg is trapped under the wall; I couldn't free her.
- Piper, I got help. - This isn't good.
Hey, Wes, we need a tourniquet, an IV kit and some fluids.
All right?
Weak radial pulse.
- Anything else hurt? - Just my leg.
She's going into hemorrhagic shock.
She can't afford to lose any more blood.
- Tourniquet. - You are gonna be fine.
Worst-case scenario, you get some well-deserved
time off with pay.
Wes can find the upside to anything.
It's nauseating.
I could use a little time away from you, Pollyanna.
I mean, you guys have been working together
for about a decade now.
Tourniquet's on, but it's not stopping the bleed.
We've done everything we can out here.
We need to get her inside.
Wes, give me a hand?
Help me get this thing off of her.
Damn it, the cell service is still down.
He's having a seizure.
We need Cain or he's gonna die.
Ugh...
Damn it.
We should reduce the fracture.
That might buy us some more time.
- Wes, you ready? - You are now officially
the most needy patient I've ever had.
Mm. Last thing I wanted to do is die needy.
Not gonna happen, Pipe.
All right, you ready?
Okay. One,
two...
It's better, but she's losing a lot of blood.
Guys, I-I don't feel so good.
We lost the pulse.
Grab the defibrillator.
Starting compressions.
We have to amputate her leg before she bleeds out.
Wes, have someone page Dr. Voss.
We need her now.
Damage could've been much worse.
Guess only one side of the hospital got hit.
Tell me about the patient.
I got a ridiculous consult about a woman with sickle cell
who's here for myeloablative chemo prior to gene therapy.
Rose Williams?
Yeah. How do you know her?
- What happened? - She fell and bonked her head.
I told them maybe don't call
unless there's an actual neurosurgical problem, but...
No. We'll see her.
Dr. Ward, please come to admitting
for a new patient assessment.
Rose.
This is Dr. Sutton, my resident.
Tell us what happened.
Oh, it's so stupid.
I fell in the bathroom and hit my head.
I'm sure I'm fine.
Okay, well, we'll just see.
Full power's back on.
I see you started chemo.
Yeah. They're blasting my marrow
and preparing me for gene therapy.
I knew it'd be tough, but...
...this is really doing a number on me.
Well, if anyone can handle it, it's you.
Pupils are equal, round and reactive.
Can you follow my finger?
I haven't seen you since Waylon's.
Yeah, I'm sorry, I've just been, been really busy.
Listen, given the effects that the chemo
is having on your bone marrow, I want to get you a head CT.
Dr. Sutton can finish the exam.
- Squeeze my fingers, please? - Uh...
So, Sammie's nose just started bleeding on its own?
Yeah, apparently, it's been happening

It's a big adjustment.

Uh, we-we didn't ask.
Well, they didn't tell us. We...
We were just so thrilled there was a healthy little girl

the first moment we met her,

We took her to the ER and found out

They told us to take her home, make her comfortable

Well, I-I said

this is more than just an ordinary nosebleed.

Do not attempt to leave the hospital.

with the sad looks from people

I loathe pity.

you can both use a distraction.

Tumor in the pancreas wrapped around the stomach,

This is inoperable.
It's an inflammatory myofibroblastic tumor.
It's a death sentence.
Unless we can tag you in.

Pioneered by the legendary Dr. Kato
at Columbia Presbyterian.
You want to take out all of her abdominal organs,

Yeah, this is the highest-risk surgery

And I-I wanted to wait,
but the tumors have occluded

That means she has to have the surgery today.
We're the only chance she's got.
Well, say no more. Let's go save a life.
She likes you.
She seems lovely.
You like her?
I'm only asking
because she couldn't take her eyes off you,
and you couldn't bolt out of there fast enough.

and vice versa. What's the big deal?
First off, she's not actually my patient.
Second, mind your own business.
When you tell someone to mind their own business,
it just confirms what it is you don't want them to think.
How I feel about Rose, and how I choose
to interact with her is not something
I need to explain to a resident.
Mind your business.
I don't see anything. You?
No bleeds.
We'll need to monitor her.
Dr. Cain?
Thank God. I'm with Dr. Devi in the sim lab.

I just sent you a photo.
Okay, by the locations,
my money's on an epidural hematoma

You need to get him to an OR immediately.

Okay.

my bad, Jessica.

Okay.

Apply pressure.

What else?

We don't have electrocautery.
Does he have a soldering iron?

Hey.
We tried everything.
Amputation was her only chance, but she lost too much blood.

It's always been other people who have doubted me.
That being said, I'm happy Dr. Pravesh was with me today.
No, no. This is your moment.
Again, well done.
Let's go.
These are worse than you made them out to be.
Per usual.
Better me than you.
Look...
I know you want to work right up until you go to labor

I'm ready.

For me and for her.
Mm.
